name: Corn stover, at conversion plant, 2022
description:
This process transports corn stover to the conversion plant. It does so using transportation modal allocation from the USDA Ethanol Backgrounder (2007), assuming those current allocations are applicable to stover and for year 2022. Distances for each mode are from a combination of references; still missing a good distance estimate for barge, but since the share of barge transportation is ~2%, the final result will not be sensititive to this parameter. Infrastructure impacts are included in this process by calling the Ecoinvent "transport" processes. 
The production of corn stover feedstock utilized in this transport process assigns inputs to corn stover based on activities and inputs that are required for the growth and harvest and preprocessing of corn stover and none of the activities or inputs that would normally be used to produce, harvest and preprocess corn grain (so-called "incremental allocation").

processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription: All information can be accessed by everybody.

exchanges.description: This is the most stringest European emission standard for lorries, though presumably considerably higher than standards in place in 2022.  Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)

assuming barge is for dry goods, barge tanker for liquid. This equation for weight, right? This process relates to "average" (current) barges, even though emissions will presumably be considerably lower in 2022.  Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)

This process uses European train data extrapolated to US by ecoinvent. This process relates to "average" (current) trains, even though emissions will presumably be considerably lower in 2022.   Assumes backhauling of gasoline (i.e., no attributable empty return trip)
